bibl.idno: The Papers of Henry Rose Carter [manuscript] ; HEALTHSCI MS-10.

div1.p: Malaria [From the Henry Rose Carter Papers]

div1.head: Newspaper clipping, Press-Knick, January 16, 1915
div1.p:
NEW YORK
88 PARK PLACE
BOSTON
62 DEVONSHIRE ST.

ALLIED WITH OFFICES IN CHICAGO, MINNEAPOLIS
DENVER, SAN FRANCISCO AND LONDON
CABLE ADDRESS CLIPBURO

In many parts of the United States
malarial fever and chills and fever,
due to malarial infection, cause more
injury than all other diseases com-
bined. This is the unqualified as-
sertion of Dr. H. R. Carter, of the
United States public health service,
who has issued a malaria catechism.
It deals with the subject in question
and answer form, explaining what ma-
laria is, what effects it has, how in-
fection may be prevented, and how
the disease may be cured. The im-
portance of the subject justifies the
efforts of the government to instruct
public opinion about it. Incidentally
it may be remarked that the govern-
ment publications are now generally
written in a much more readable style
than formerly and that they are read
by millions who used to throw them
into the waste basket as useless sta-
tistical junk.

Carter Harrison awaits his wife's
consent to make his sixth pace for
mayor of Chicago.
